{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3600681,"name":null,"username":"AutumnPlanet","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/autumnplanet/{size}/260647_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T22:38:18.348Z","cooked":"

I don’t know what you call these tips, but I put an example in the image.

This season we had great problems because of these tips, they were constantly coming out and it took a really long time to tighten them back. So how do you tighten these tips?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T22:38:18.348Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":81,"reads":744,"readers_count":743,"score":553.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/new-electrical-lead-tips/501015/33","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"New Electrical Lead, Tips?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70504,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3600684,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T22:44:25.841Z","cooked":"

We use a hydraulic wire crimper to crimp the terminals/lugs on 6awg and 4awg wires.

This is the one we currently use - AMZCNC 12 Ton Hydraulic Wire Crimper Battery Cable Lug Terminal Crimping Tool w/ 10 Dies (8AWG~4/0AWG Crimping Tool) - Amazon.com (Amazon Affiliate link)

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-22T22:44:25.841Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":724,"readers_count":723,"score":284.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":"AllenGregoryIV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://amzn.to/4cKItpE","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"AMZCNC 12 Ton Hydraulic Wire Crimper Battery Cable Lug Terminal Crimping Tool w/ 10 Dies (8AWG~4/0AWG Crimping Tool) - Amazon.com","clicks":137}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":10647,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/2","custom_user_title":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3600705,"name":"Joseph Walters","username":"Jwal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-22T23:14:57.720Z","cooked":"

I’m hoping OP is asking about crimping, but for completness:

On the battery terminal to battery cable connection you use a bolted joint. Most bolted joints will do if you do NOT carry the battery by the cables and handle your batteries with care.

If you are passionate about battery connections, and I am, or you particularly enjoy 1-tool/1-handed installation these products are a common recommendation:

The Thrifty Bot

QTY 2 - Grasshopper Nut for Battery Terminals

The Grasshopper nut, produced with the help of James Cole-Henry from FRC team 95, The Grasshoppers, is an innovative battery solution to increase the reliability of battery terminal connections. Kit contents:  x2 Grasshopper Nuts x2 PEM Nuts,...

Price: USD 7.99

Additionally you may find this presentation inciteful about battery construction, troubleshooting, and the importance of your battery to match preparedness:

Champs 2025 Presentation- Robot Power Delivery: Maximizing Performance - Friday 10am General Forum
Here is the video of my Houston presentation on battery characterization and power wiring. [Robot Power Delivery - Shane Trent - FRC#4561 - Houston 2025] Thanks! Shane

Grasshopper Nut for Battery Terminals","clicks":41},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/champs-2025-presentation-robot-power-delivery-maximizing-performance-friday-10am/499634/5","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Champs 2025 Presentation- Robot Power Delivery: Maximizing Performance - Friday 10am","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":10647,"username":"AllenGregoryIV","name":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601289,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T14:52:11.265Z","cooked":"

One caution, the linked tool (and essentially every other low-cost tool of this type that I’ve found, unfortunately) has dies sized for metric wire sizes, not AWG. After a 2022 on field failure due to this, I’ve been trying to spread awareness. The listing shows 10mm2 and 16mm2 die sizes, but 6AWG wire is actually 13.3mm2, so if you use the 16 your crimp isn’t tight and if you use the 10 it’s overcrimped and distorted.

FWIW we use a Temco TH-0006 that provides true AWG dies. Unfortunately it’s also $150, but we consider it a good investment and it will last a very long time.

We also have been very happy with the power werx crimper which has extended handles and is less awkward to grip.

https://powerwerx.com/hyd-2-hydraulic-crimping-tool

Not ideal, but if you find yourself with the oversized crimper/die and can’t afford the more expensive tool, you can do what we’ve done before which is to slide a thin piece of aluminum to crimp along with the terminal.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T15:36:47.890Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":473,"readers_count":472,"score":129.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48574,"username":"bbonner","name":"Brett B Bonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601468,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T16:30:15.549Z","cooked":"
ns3517:

We also have been very happy with the power werx crimper

The great thing about this crimper and the other Harbor-Fright and other similar variants can use the corresponding AWG-sized Temco dies. You can get a whole set or order them individually.

Hydraulic Cable Lug Crimper TH0006 V2.0 5 US TON 12 AWG to 00 (2/0) Electrical Terminal Cable Wire Tool Kit with 18 Die Sets - TEMCo Industrial for the crimper and whole set crimp dies (that’s the same tool as @bbonner posted)

TEMCo TH0416 18-Pair Die Set for the TH0006 Hydraulic Cable Lug Crimper for the full set of dies alone

TH0006 single size Die set for wire size 6 AWG for the single 6AWG die (might as well get the full set as it include “+” sizes for the common crimp sizes which can be nice to crimping connectors that are slightly larger)

They even sell some parts like seals (and more) for those crimpers which surprised me for a sub $50 tool.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T16:31:54.723Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":437,"readers_count":436,"score":187.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://temcoindustrial.com/hydraulic-cable-lug-crimper-th0006-v2-0-5-us-ton-12-awg-to-00-2-0-electrical-terminal-cable-wire-tool-kit-with-18-die-sets/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Hydraulic Cable Lug Crimper TH0006 V2.0 5 US TON 12 AWG to 00 (2/0) Electrical Terminal Cable Wire Tool Kit with 18 Die Sets - TEMCo Industrial","clicks":19},{"url":"https://temcoindustrial.com/th0006-single-size-die-set-for-wire-size-6-awg/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"TH0006 single size Die set for wire size 6 AWG","clicks":10},{"url":"https://temcoindustrial.com/temco-th0416-18-piece-die-set-for-the-th0006-hydraulic-cable-lug-crimper/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"TEMCo TH0416 18-Pair Die Set for the TH0006 Hydraulic Cable Lug Crimper","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/7","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601483,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T16:37:52.444Z","cooked":"

Regardless of the connection type (crimped lug, lever nut, push-button, screw terminal, solder, etc…) one should to a tug test, immediately after making the connection for each wire, to verify that the connection is good and to detect bad connections. Of course, one must exercise good judgement for how much force should be applied to the wire to prevent damaging the smaller wires.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T16:37:52.444Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":375,"readers_count":374,"score":140.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601545,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T17:15:33.797Z","cooked":"
philso:

one should to a tug test, immediately after making the connection for each wire, to verify that the connection is good and to detect bad connections

That is huge! I stress with our electrical team (especially but really all subteams) “Have someone check your work”.

Whether it’s crimps, or nuts, or bolts, or anything else, it’s the cheapest place to detect, fix, and prevent a future problem. It can feel like an uphill battle but progress is clearly being made on our team; ESPECIALLY when something is found before it becomes a problem and members get the rush from PREVENTING an almost certain failure of some sort on the field.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T17:15:33.797Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":365,"readers_count":364,"score":108.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601570,"name":null,"username":"AutumnPlanet","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/autumnplanet/{size}/260647_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T17:33:40.322Z","cooked":"

First of all, thank you very much for your suggestions.

As I mentioned, these battery ferrules could come out at any time no matter how much we checked, and if I remember correctly, we had problems in one of our matches because of this.

I will consult with my team to buy the products you mentioned, but since I am Turkish, it seems difficult to bring these products to Turkey (in terms of customs and taxes, if the product is 150 dollars, we need to buy it for 300 dollars). Nevertheless, if I can find an awg type plier in Turkey, I will consider it.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T17:33:40.322Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":337,"readers_count":336,"score":72.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70504,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601863,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T21:05:13.279Z","cooked":"

At a previous workplace, the assembly workers would have one of their coworkers check their work. The QC person would then check the work again.

One last tip is if there is a pair of wires, check each individual wire separately. I have found instances where one wire in a pair was loose but doing a tug test on the pair indicated they were good because one was good.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T21:06:14.160Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":307,"readers_count":306,"score":91.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":40142,"username":"zog","name":"Chris Herzog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602071,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T01:25:28.916Z","cooked":"

Lever crimpers are more work to use and have fewer size choices, but much cheaper:

amazon.com

iCrimp Cable Lug Crimping Tool for Heavy Duty Wire Lugs, Battery Terminal,...

iCrimp Cable Lug Crimping Tool for Heavy Duty Wire Lugs, Battery Terminal, Copper Lugs AWG 8-1/0 - Amazon.com

I have one for home use, but have not competition tested it.

Quality can be more dubious: ours made flashing so large I was concerned if there was any copper lug material left at the seam to have effectively cold-welded the joint or if it all just squeezed out the sides!

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T03:06:59.636Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":283,"readers_count":282,"score":56.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602304,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T14:04:46.607Z","cooked":"

Interesting, this design is virtually identical to the original metric-sized one that was the source of our bad crimps, but unlike ours the rotating dies appear to be marked with actual AWG sizes. This makes me wonder if it’s true-to-size or just re-marked for the US market. In any case I think it’s the first inexpensive tool of this design I’ve seen that isn’t obviously metric on close inspection.

Also, it’s worth noting that even a not-quite-right-sized metric die is a better option than the makeshift solutions I’ve seen used (and helped teams to fix the results of). These include the “squish it in a vise”, “crush it under an arbor press”, “smash it with a hammer”, and “Vise-Grips are almost like a crimp tool” methods.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":39,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T14:04:46.607Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":256,"readers_count":255,"score":116.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500208,"topic_slug":"how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables","display_username":"Brett B Bonner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48574,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6328 Mentor - Electrical/Controls"},"post_url":"/t/how-do-you-tighten-the-ends-of-the-battery-cables/500208/14","custom_user_title":"6328 Mentor - Electrical/Controls","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602310,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T14:12:56.764Z","cooked":"

For the record, “hammer crimpers” are a thing that I’ve used successfully for stationary r&d builds in the 0-000awg ranges.

Not necessarily a good tool for robots or professional electricians. But they exist and work.

Now, straight up hammering it with no tool - that’s a different matter

","username":"IndySam","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/indysam/{size}/111341_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T14:18:57.212Z","cooked":"
AutumnPlanet:

I will consult with my team to buy the products you mentioned, but since I am Turkish, it seems difficult to bring these products to Turkey (in terms of customs and taxes, if the product is 150 dollars, we need to buy it for 300 dollars). Nevertheless, if I can find an awg type plier in Turkey, I will consider it.

If you can work with other teams in your area and by one set that would be best. It’s the kind of tool that is easy to share and not often used.

s-neff:

“hammer crimpers” are a thing

Yes. I’ve occasionally wondered whether these might be viable as a low-cost team alternative, but I have no experience to comment on how well they work in practice.

s-neff:

straight up hammering it with no tool

This was the technique I’ve seen employed
